data.title: Early explorers
data.meta_description: Find out how early explorers navigated the seas before they had maps to guide them.
data.text:
Transcript

Early explorers didn’t actually know where they were going when they set out to discover new land.

They had to draw and redraw maps as they went.

One of the biggest challenges was calculating their longitude, how far east or west they were.

longitude

In the 15th century they used a method called dead reckoning.

Dead reckoning is based on the ship’s previous position, its speed, and its direction, which was taken using a compass.

Dead Reckoning

Speed was measured using a log and a line.

The ship log was a piece of wood that would drag a rope line overboard.

A sandglass was used to time the letting out of the rope, which was knotted at regular intervals.

Sailors could tell how fast their ship was travelling by counting the number of knots that passed overboard before the sandglass ran out.

We still use the term knots to refer to the speed of boats.

But using dead reckoning wasn't very accurate.

dead reckoning

used to estimate longitude

A breakthrough came in the 18th century, when explorers such as James Cook started using watches called timekeepers, or chronometers.

James Cook

1728–1779

Chronometers were set to show the time of a known location.

Chronometers

The Greenwich Observatory in London, UK, at longitude zero degrees, was a popular choice.

Greenwich Observatory

London, UK

Having set sail, explorers could now calculate their longitude by comparing the time in their current location, taken from the position of the Sun, to the time in London.

For example, when the Sun was at its highest position, they knew it was noon.

time taken from Sun

So if the chronometer said it was 2pm in London, they knew they must be two time zones away, or 30 degrees west of zero degrees longitude – in the middle of the Atlantic!

time on chronometer

chronometer

watch used to calculate longitude

Today sailors use GPS to accurately map their longitude, but navigating the seas can still be a great adventure.
